newsitem.title: USA: Orange County, Merrill Lynch trial set for Sept '98.
newsitem.headline: Orange County, Merrill Lynch trial set for Sept '98.

text.p: A judge on Monday set a September 1998 trial date for Orange County, California's $2-billion-plus lawsuit against brokerage giant Merrill Lynch & Co.
The county filed the lawsuit against Merrill Lynch in January 1995, alleging the brokerage firm sold it risky securities in violation of state law.
Merrill Lynch has denied any wrongdoing and has asserted that the losses were the result of the county's "ill-advised" decision to declare bankruptcy.
At a court hearing in Santa Ana late on Monday, U.S. District Judge Gary Taylor told the county and Merrill Lynch that the case would go to trial on September 15, 1998.

The date was not a surprise to many people involved in the case. Merrill Lynch had argued that it needed more than one year to prepare its defence because of the complexity of the case. The county sought less time.
"We will prepare for trial and expect to be ready by the date set by the judge," Merrill Lynch spokesman Timothy Gilles said after the hearing.
County attorneys said the 1998 trial date was fair.
"We'd like it to be a little sooner, but that's the judge's job," county attorney Michael Hennigan said.
Orange County filed for protection under Chapter 9 of the federal Bankruptcy Code on December 6, 1994 after sustaining investment losses of more than $1.6 billion.
The county emerged from bankruptcy last June.
It has sued several firms to recover the funds it lost, including Merrill Lynch, the credit rating agency Standard & Poor's Corp and brokerage firm Morgan Stanley & Co.
